Award.AwardTitle: NSMDS: Improving Material Safety through the Minimization of Oxidative Stress Potential: A mechanistic understanding of ROS generation in in vitro and in vivo systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the NSF Division of Chemistry and the Environmental Protection Agency, through a program of Networks for Sustainable Molecular Design and Synthesis, support Professors Paul Anastas and William Jorgensen and Dr. Evan Beach of Yale University in establishing a Network for Improving Material Safety through Minimization of Oxidative Stress Potential. This network includes scientists at Baylor University, George Washington University, and the University of Washington who each have critical roles to play in advancing the goals of the project. This network advances the science of rational design of chemicals and materials for reduced adverse biological activity. Utilizing empirical toxicity data, both in vivo and in vitro, computational models to describe molecular events that trigger toxic responses are being developed. Through an iterative process of laboratory and computational studies, design guidelines (physical and chemical property parameters) are being created for molecules with minimal potential to cause oxidative stress through multiple toxicity pathways. This strategy involves preparing model training sets based on chemicals relevant to toxicity associated with reactive oxygen species (ROS); using computational chemistry to model and predict chemical pathways that result in oxidative stress; modeling and measuring both in vivo and in vitro impacts of chemicals that generate ROS; and correlating in silico and experimental results to develop design parameters for minimal ROS activity.

Chemicals and the materials created through advanced chemistry are the basis of our society and our economy. Yet, with all of the excellent toxicology that has helped us understand and in some cases predict toxicity associated with industrial chemicals, little progress has been made in answering the fundamental scientific questions that would allow for the design of chemicals with reduced hazard to humans and the environment. Although the vast majority of commercial chemicals are not intended to have biological activity, unintended toxicity is largely due to the lack of guidelines for coupling efficacy of function with design for reduced hazard. New guidelines and design tools aid in formulation of existing chemical products and guide innovation in safe alternatives. Acceptance and implementation of these tools are promoted by educational campaigns for students and professional chemists. Additional efforts seek to inform chemical policy by providing a means of managing classes of chemicals by common properties rather than on a case-by-case basis, with the overall goal to promote innovation through the use of rational chemical design to reduce or eliminate the toxic effects of new materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

 

The potential threat that commercial chemicals can pose to our society and the environment through unintended biological activity has become increasingly clear in recent years. Unfortunately, extensive human health and ecotoxicological testing of all new products is not feasible and there has been little progress made in minimizing the undesired biological and environmental effects of commodity chemicals using systematic design tools. Consequentially, there is a need for improved tools and guidelines for use by those who design new chemicals or processes for commercial use. 

 

To meet this challenge, a multidisciplinary team of scientists from four different universities came together as a team and formed MoDRN, the Molecular Design Research Network [https://modrn.yale.edu]. The network was made possible by funding in the form of a grant from the NSF and the EPA [CHE-1339637]. A major goal of the Network was to advance the science of the rational design of chemicals and materials for reduced hazard and to elucidate guidelines for a safer design of next-generation molecules. This goal was grounded in the 12 Principles of Green Chemistry, [insert link] and in particular, the fourth principle that states “chemical products should be designed to preserve efficacy of function while minimizing toxicity”.

 

The Research team generated data and results that will advance the science of the rational design of new chemicals with unintended toxciity and in particular will aid in the reduction of economic and ethical costs of animal screening for adverse effects of these new chemicals. Beyond the immediate results obtained, the project provided a powerful roadmap for other such collaborations: lowering barriers among scientific disciplines and catalyzing advancements in chemical design and toxicological science beyond the scope of the project itself.  Critically, the results and analysis of the team was published in peer-reviewed scientific journals. Together with the Education team, the MoDRN team will publish over 31 scientific and educational articles.

 

Another goal of the grant was the adoption of the developed approaches by practitioners in the field. Consequently, education was critical to the success of this project. The project team developed interdisciplinary training and modular learning materials to bridge gaps between chemists, toxicologists, engineers, and other scientists. Additionally, MoDRN created The Safer Chemical Design Game, an online educational computer game that is focused on teaching safer chemical design to students and practitioners. Finally, the MoDRN team developed a series of educational modules and videos that can be used in high school and university curriculum that are freely available on the MoDRN website to instructors.
